Name: Dinitrogen oxide
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Transported as refrigerated liquefied gases (UNRTDG)

Name: hydrogen iodide
Classification: Gases under pressure - Liquefied gas(Low pressure liquefied gas)
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of "the critical temp: 151.0degC" (Merck, 13th, 2001) and the boiling point: -35.1degC (at 1atm).

Name: Hydrobromic acid
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of the critical temp: >65degC and the steam pressure: >3 atm at 20degC.

Name: Nitrogen monoxide
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Transported as refrigerated liquefied gases (UNRTDG)

Name: nitrogen dioxide
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: boron trichloride
Classification: Gases under pressure - Liquefied gas(Low pressure liquefied gas)
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of "the critical temp: 178degC" (HSDB, 2002)

Name: Butane
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: 1,3-Butadiene
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -4degC (ICSC 2004), and the critical temperature is 161.8degC (HSDB (2005)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1010)(UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Tetrafluoroethylene
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -75.9degC (Lide (84th, 2003)) and the critical temperature is 33.3degC (HSDB (2006)) - i.e., "liquefied gas."  Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1081) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

Name: Dimethylamine
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: Dichlorotetrafluoroethane
Rationale for classification:
The boiling point is 3.4degC (Lide (84th, 2003)) and the critical temperature is 145.6degC (HSDB (2006)), i.e., "liquefied gas" (1,1-form). 
The boiling point is 4.1degC (ICSC (1999)) and the critical temperature is 145.7degC (Merck (13th, 2001)), i.e., "liquefied gas" (1,2-form).

Name: Hydrogen
Classification: Gases under pressure - Compressed gas or Refrigerated liquefied gas
Hazard statement:
Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Contains refrigerated gas; may cause cryogenic burns or injury

Name: Carbon black
Classification: Gases under pressure - Not applicable(Materials of animal or vegetable origin and mineral origin)
Rationale for classification: Solid (GHS definition)

Name: N-methyldithiocarbamic acid
Classification: Gases under pressure - Not applicable (ammonium salt)
Rationale for classification: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition. The free acid cannot be classified due to lack of data.

Name: diborane(6)
Classification: Gases under pressure - High pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Compressed gas because of "the steam pressure: 3999kPa at 17degC" (HSDB, 2006) and ">280kPa at 20degC" (GHS definition). High pressure liquefied gas because of the critidal temp: 16.7degC"(HSDB, 2006: ICSC(J), 1990) which is between -50degC and 65degC.

Name: arsenic pentachloride
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Not specified whether it is a high or low pressure liquefied gas, due to lack of data on a critical temp, though it seems to be stable in a liquid state at extremely low temperature (about -50degC)

Name: chlorophenol
Classification: Gases under pressure - Not applicable (o, m, p-)
Rationale for classification: Not Gas (GHS definition) (o, m, p-)

Name: sulphuryl difluoride
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of "the critical temp: -20 or 96degC" (HSDB, 2002).

Name: 2-Chloro-1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane; HCFC-124
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -12degC (Lide (84th, 2003)), and the critical temperature is 122.2degC (HSDB (2006)) - i.e., liquefied gas.

Name: carbonyl difluoride
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Compressed liquedfied gas according to a report, though the critical temprature is unknown (ICSC(J), 2003)

Name: Bromochlorodifluoromethane; Halone-1211
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -4degC (ICSC (1999)), and the critical temperature is 154degC (Lide (84th, 2003)), i.e., "Liquefied gas." Classified into Division 2.2 (UN#1974) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: oxalonitrile
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of "the steam pressure: 11.5 atm at 50degC"(GESTIS, 2006) which is >3 atm, and "the critical temp: 128.3degC" (HSDB, 2005) which is >65degC

Name: Ketene
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 380degC (Lange, 16th, 2005)

Name: Formaldehyde
Classification: Gases under pressure - Liquefied gas (gas), Not applicable (aqueous solution)
Rationale for classification: Classified as "liquefied gas," based on the description in ICSC (2004) (boiling point: -20degC) and HSDB (2005) (critical temperature: 137.2-141.2degC). There is no applicable substance listed in the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (gas). Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition (aqueous solution)

Name: cyanogen chloride
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 215degC (AIR LIQUIDE, Safety Data Sheet, 31/07/2002)

Name: bromoethylene
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: methyl nitrite
Classification: Gases under pressure - Liquefied gas(Low pressure liquefied gas)
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of "the melting point: -16degC and the boiling point: -12degC" (Lide, 85th, 2004)

Name: Carbon monoxide
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Transported as compressed gases because of the critical temp: <-140degC.

Name: hexafluoroacetone
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: Methane
Classification: Gases under pressure - Compressed gas or Refrigerated liquefied gas
Hazard statement:
Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Contains refrigerated gas; may cause cryogenic burns or injury

Name: Bromomethane; Methyl bromide
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is 4degC (ICSC (1999)), and the critical temperature is 194degC (Merck (13th, 2001)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.3 (UN#1062 (those not exceeding chloropicrin 2%)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Ethane
Classification: Gases under pressure - Compressed gas or Refrigerated liquefied gas
Hazard statement:
Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Contains refrigerated gas; may cause cryogenic burns or injury

Name: Ethene
Classification: Gases under pressure - Compressed gas or Refrigerated liquefied gas
Hazard statement:
Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Contains refrigerated gas; may cause cryogenic burns or injury

Name: Ethyne
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Gas compressed and dissolved in the liquid phase solvent. (ICSC(J), 2003)

Name: Chloromethane; Methyl chloride
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -24.2degC (ICSC 2000), and the critical temperature is 143.10degC (HSDB 2005) - i.e., liquefied gases. Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1063) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Methanamine
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 156.9degC

Name: Methanethiol
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 196.8degC

Name: Propane
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: 1-Propyne
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 400.8 K (127.6degC)

Name: Sulfur dioxide
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: Chloroethane
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is 12.5degC (ICSC 2004), and the critical temperature is 187.2degC (Merck (13th, 2001)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#1037) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Chloroethylene; Vinyl chloride
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -13degC (ICSC 2000), and the critical temperature is 151.5degC (HSDB 2005) - i.e., liquefied gas. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 2.1(UN#1086) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Ethene, fluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: Ethanamine
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of "the critical temp: 182.9degC or 183degC" (HSDB, 2002) .

Name: Ethylene oxide
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is 11degC (ICSC 2004), and the critical temperature is 196degC(HSDB 2005) -- i.e., liquefied gases. Classified into Category 2.1and Category 2.3 (UN# 1040) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Ethene, 1,1-difluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: dichlorofluoromethane
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of the critical temp: >65degC.

Name: Phosgene
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is 8degC (ICSC (2004)), and the critical temperature is 182degC (HSDB (2006)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.3 and Class 8 (UN#1076) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Methane, chlorodifluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of the critical temp: >65degC and the steam pressure: >3 atm at 20degC

Name: Trimethylamine
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: Methane, bromotrifluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: 1-Chloro-1,1-difluoroethane; HCFC-142b
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -9degC (HSDB (2006)), and the critical temperature is 137.1degC (HSDB (2006)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Divisions 2.1 (UN#2517) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: Methane, dichlorodifluoro-
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of the critical temp: >65degC.

Name: Chlorotrifluoromethane; CFC-13
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -84degC (ICSC (1999)), and the critical temperature is 28.8degC (HSDB(2006)) - i.e., liquefied gas.

Name: Ethane, 1,2-dichlorotetrafluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Transported as refrigerated liquefied gases (UNRTDG)

Name: Ethane, chloropentafluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of the critical temp: >65degC.

Name: Borane, trifluoro-
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Compressed gas because of "the critical temp: -12.25degC to -12.25degC" (Hommel, 1991: HSDB, 2005), "the critical pressure: 4.98MPa" (HSDB, 2005), and the state in a usual circulation.

Name: Hydrochloric acid
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG No. 1050, Class: 2.3. "Critical temp: 51 degC" (Hommel, 1991)

Name: Ammonia
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 132.4degC (Merck, 13th, 2001)

Name: Arsenic acid
Classification: Gases under pressure - Not applicable (aqueous solution)
Rationale for classification: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition (aqueous solution)

Name: Fluorine
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -188degC (ICSC (2004)) and the critical temperature is -129degC (Merck (13th, 2001)), corresponding to "compressed gases" Those compressed are classified into Division 2.3  (UN#1045) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

Name: Chlorine
Classification: Gases under pressure - Low pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of the critical temp: 143.8 to 144degC.

Name: germanium tetrahydride
Classification: Gases under pressure - High pressure liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: 34.85degC (Hommel, 1991)

Name: Hydrogen sulfide
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Critical temp: >-50degC (Partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC)

Name: Dihydrogen selenide
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -41degC (ICSC 2004), and the critical temperature is 137degC (Merck (13th, 2001)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Divisions 2.1and 2.3 (UN#2202) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: phosphorous trifluoride
Classification: Gases under pressure - Liquefied gas(High pressure liquefied gas)
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: High pressure liquefied gas because of "the critical temp: -2.05degC"(Merck, 13th, 2001)

Name: sulphur tetrafluoride
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of "the boiling point: -40degC" (ICSC(J), 2003) and partially liquid at temperatures above -50degC.

Name: Selenium hexafluoride
Classification: Gases under pressure - Liquefied gas(Low pressure liquefied gas)
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Low pressure liquefied gas because of "the triple point: -34.6degC" (Lide, 85th, 2004) and "the critical temp: 72.35degC"(HSDB, 2003)

Name: Tungsten hexafluoride
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is 17.5degC (Merck (13th, 2001)) and the critical temperature is 171degC (Lide (84th, 2003)), i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.3 (UN#2196) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

Name: pentafluoroarsorane
Classification: Gases under pressure - Compressed gas or Liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Not specified whether it is a compressed or liquefied gas, due to lack of data on a critical temp, though "the boiling point is -53.2degC"(Merck, 13th, 2001)

Name: Arsine
Rationale for classification: The boiling point is -62degC (ICSC (2004)) and the critical temperature is 100degC (HSDB (2006)), i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.1 and Division 2.3 (UN#2188) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

Name: chlorine trifluoride
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Liquefied gas because of "the critical temp: 153degC" (Weiss, 2nd, 1985).

Name: phosphine
Classification: Gases under pressure - Compressed gas or Liquefied gas
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated

Name: silane
Hazard statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
Rationale for classification: Compressed gas because of "the critical temp: -4degC" (Hommel, 1991) and the actual state in a usual circulation.

Name: Chlorotrifluoroethane
Rationale for classification: No data available on critical temperature. Classified into Division 2.2. (UN#1983 (1-chloro-2,2,2-trifluoroethane), used as refrigerant gas) by the UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.
